articles.headline: Europe’s Case Against Google Might Help Rivals More Than Consumers
articles.snippet: The driving force pushing the recent European action against Google’s search engine was a consortium of corporate rivals.
articles.abstract: The driving force pushing the recent European action against Google’s search engine was a consortium of corporate rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a persistent (and thus far fruitless) effort to hobble giant American technology companies, the European Union has again taken aim at Alphabet’s Google search engine.

articles.headline: Why Is Productivity So Weak? Three Theories
articles.snippet: The rate of economic output is not increasing much. Or is there work below the surface that will pay big dividends in the future?
articles.abstract: The rate of economic output is not increasing much. Or is there work below the surface that will pay big dividends in the future?
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 151 million Americans count themselves employed, a number that has risen sharply in the last few years. The question is this: What are they doing all day?

articles.headline: University in Turmoil Over Scalia Tribute and Koch Role
articles.snippet: The planned renaming of a law school after Justice Antonin Scalia is creating worries among faculty and students that the public university is becoming an ideological outpost.
articles.abstract: The planned renaming of a law school after Justice Antonin Scalia is creating worries among faculty and students that the public university is becoming an ideological outpost.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, students and faculty at George Mason University paid little attention as Charles G. Koch and other conservatives helped transform their once sleepy commuter school in the suburbs of the nation’s capital into a leading producer of free-market scholarship. The effort, after all, was focused on a few specific departments like economics and law and attracted little attention outside conservative circles.

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Gender-Based Attacks on Hillary Clinton Have Calculated Risk
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump, the Republican favorite, has already proved willing to attack Mrs. Clinton in ways that many women find sexist and that her supporters consider out of bounds.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump, the Republican favorite, has already proved willing to attack Mrs. Clinton in ways that many women find sexist and that her supporters consider out of bounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the nation on the verge of a presidential election between the first woman to lead a major party and an opponent accused of misogyny, Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump are digging in for a fight in which he is likely to attack her precisely because she is a woman.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Health Care Companies See Scale as the Only Way to Compete
articles.snippet: Deals worth over $40 billion were announced Thursday as companies teamed up to become leading providers and gain clout to negotiate with hospitals and insurers.
articles.abstract: Deals worth over $40 billion were announced Thursday as companies teamed up to become leading providers and gain clout to negotiate with hospitals and insurers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A spate of deals on Thursday showed that health care companies are convinced, regardless of tax benefits, that bigger is not only better, it is necessary.

articles.headline: Vijay Mallya, Indian ‘King of Good Times,’ Dethroned by Debt
articles.snippet: The beer-and-airline magnate left the country ahead of creditors, as bad corporate loans hurt the economy and Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s agenda.
articles.abstract: The beer-and-airline magnate left the country ahead of creditors, as bad corporate loans hurt the economy and Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Three months before he left India with $1.4 billion in unpaid bills hanging over his head, the man who called himself the King of Good Times gave a party for himself.

articles.headline: Puerto Rico Debt Deadline Looms With Washington Still Haggling
articles.snippet: As a May 1 deadline nears, terms of a bill to rescue the island are unresolved, risking greater injury to its ailing economy.
articles.abstract: As a May 1 deadline nears, terms of a bill to rescue the island are unresolved, risking greater injury to its ailing economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In December, House Speaker Paul D. Ryan instructed lawmakers to find a “responsible solution” to Puerto Rico’s debt crisis in the first three months of this year, giving the island plenty of time to prepare for a May 1 deadline on a $422 million debt payment.

articles.headline: Europe’s Economy, After 8-Year Detour, Is Fitfully Back on Track
articles.snippet: The eurozone, the 19 countries that use the euro, has finally edged back above its precrisis level, but doubts persist about its prospects.
articles.abstract: The eurozone, the 19 countries that use the euro, has finally edged back above its precrisis level, but doubts persist about its prospects.
articles.lead_paragraph: By one measure, the economic crisis that has long ravaged Europe is finally over.

articles.headline: A Private Equity Alum’s Guide to Better Payday Lenders
articles.snippet: A new guide on the website NerdWallet is aimed at helping borrowers avoid the trap of payday loans with punishingly high interest rates.
articles.abstract: A new guide on the website NerdWallet is aimed at helping borrowers avoid the trap of payday loans with punishingly high interest rates.

articles.headline: At Small Colleges, Harsh Lessons About Cash Flow
articles.snippet: In the last few years, small liberal arts colleges struggling under financial siege have been forced to re-examine their missions and justify their existence.
articles.abstract: In the last few years, small liberal arts colleges struggling under financial siege have been forced to re-examine their missions and justify their existence.
articles.lead_paragraph: RINDGE, N.H. — Amber Jackson remembers the moment she learned that both her majors — dance and math — had been cut from the program at Franklin Pierce University. She immediately called her mother, whose reaction was: “They can do that?”

articles.headline: Valeant’s New Skipper Is on the Same Tack
articles.snippet: Those expecting a clean sweep from Joseph C. Papa, Valeant’s new C.E.O., may be disappointed: His last company, Perrigo, pursued some Valeant-esque strategies.
articles.abstract: Those expecting a clean sweep from Joseph C. Papa, Valeant’s new C.E.O., may be disappointed: His last company, Perrigo, pursued some Valeant-esque strategies.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a deeply troubled company replaces its chief executive, it makes sense to expect the new C.E.O. to bring a fresh take to its operations. A clean sweep, so to speak.

articles.headline: ‘Zappa Plays Zappa’ Pits Zappa vs. Zappa
articles.snippet: Frank’s son Dweezil was told by the family trust, controlled by two of his siblings, that his show Zappa Plays Zappa risked huge copyright infringement fines.
articles.abstract: Frank’s son Dweezil was told by the family trust, controlled by two of his siblings, that his show Zappa Plays Zappa risked huge copyright infringement fines.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a decade, Dweezil Zappa, a son of the rock star Frank Zappa and a noted guitarist in his own right, has been paying tribute to his father’s music under the name Zappa Plays Zappa. The project, which features exacting performances of Frank Zappa’s famously complex music, has toured the world and won a Grammy.
